reasoning:
The critique targets the paper’s “scale-tipping” objection to bounded, jointly-aggregating difference-making views—one of the paper’s arguments for thinking even the main easygoing candidate is implausible. That point is relevant but not central to the overall ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion, which is also supported by (i) the earlier “fragility/product-of-factors” considerations and (ii) other objections to difference-making bounded views (e.g., stochastic dominance issues, pro-extinction risk, and concerns about aggregation). Hence moderate-low centrality.

Its refutation strength is limited because it mainly asserts a possibility (“smoothing/layering could damp tipping”) without specifying a concrete value functional that (a) remains a plausible bounded joint-aggregation view, (b) actually eliminates scale-tipping rather than relocating it, and (c) avoids the paper’s other objections. So it at most weakens that one objection somewhat.

Correctness is fairly high: it’s plausible that one could design more continuous or robust aggregation schemes, and it’s true that other domains handle sharp transitions via robustness methods. But the analogy to chaos/critical transitions is under-argued and doesn’t by itself establish that the relevant normative instability can be ‘smoothed’ without cost.

The critique is clear and focused on a single issue, with little fluff.
title: Smoothing mechanisms could stabilize bounded views against scale-tipping instability
